mods:mods.mods:abstract: The commons voted all existing taxes illegal at the end of their session. Its members also bound themselves to each other by an oath not to separate of their own accord until they had written a constitution for France. If separated by force, they agreed to meet in another place. The King had no intention of suppressing them, but censured them, and at the same time announced that his own opinions coincided substantially with theirs. A committee consisting of the King and his nobles attacked Necker and substituted for his plan one form the Count d'Artois. Necker offered to resign, but D'Artois refused. The people greeted the King with silence and sullenness, but the Duke of Orleans and Necker were received with acclamations. A run on the exchequer has begun. Necker cannot stop it because he must have funds free to continue the government. The Archbishop of Paris was attacked by a mob, which extracted from him the promise to support the third estate. Versailles is full of soldiers. The commons seems ready to eradicate all class distinctions. Jefferson feels that there is more courage than calculation to this move. The commons are indifferent to Necker's remaining in office. In the event of his departure, they intend to take immediate measure to continue payment of public debts.
